prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 370 um in zC412369/zC401417
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 370 um continuum, chance for serendipitous detection of CO 7-6/[CI] 2-1 in USB

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We predict the TIR luminosity of our targets from their SFR using the calibration by Kennicutt & Evans (2012, ARAA, 50, 531). The resulting TIR is converted to a flux density at 370 um by assuming graybody emission with an emissivity exponent beta=1.5 and a temperature of 35 K. This temperature is on the high end of what is expected for galaxies with z=2 and the SSFR observed in our galaxies (according to Eq. 5 in Magnelli et al. (2013, submitted to A&A, arXiv:1311.2956), yielding a conservative estimate of the 370 um flux. It also is consistent with the results of Yang et al. (2007, ApJ 660, 1198) for temperatures at high redshift (see their Fig. 7). For the same assumptions detailed in the [CII] science goal (assuming 80% of the emission is resolved into 1-2 beams) we expect S/N~14-7. For a 32 K temperature (as predicted by Magnelli), we expect S/N~20-10.
We have placed the CO 7-6 and [CI] 2-1 transitions in the upper sideband to maximize serendipity. It is difficult to predict the strength of these transitions, since it depends on the excitation condition in the gas, but even for pretty low excitation sources (such as the Milky Way) CO 3-2, 7-6, and [CI] 2-1 have similar fluxes in nW/m2 (Fixsen et al. 1999, ApJ 526, 207). So we expect them to be detectable with our integration time.
These galaxies are grouped in our science goals to minimize calibration overheads, since they have very similar redshifts.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in zC412369/zC401417 in the LSB
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This setup places the image sideband (USB) in a more transparent part of the atmosphere. Precision of redshift is 110 km/s (1-sigma; Lilly+ 2009).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In order to compute the expected [CII] intensity we use two methods: 1) the relation between [CII] and SFR, and 2) a photodissociation region model for general conditions Go~1e3, Go/n~1 to predict [CII]/FIR vs. CO/FIR. Both approaches yield very comparable results within the natural uncertainties. We use the Herrera Camus et al. in prep. calibration of [CII] vs. SFR for the KINGFISH sample (i.e., normal galaxies), which is compatible with the ISO results from Bosselli et al (2002) and de Looze et al. (2013). The comparison with the GOALS sample results indicates that the CII deficit does not significantly affect the calibration for star formation surface densities of the order of the average surface density in our objects (Herrera Camus et al. in prep.), but determining whether the [CII] emission is "normal" or not is one of our science goals. The corresponding equation relating SFR and [CII] luminosity is in the main text of the proposal. We also predict luminosities using the calibration of Sargsyan et al. (2012), which corresponds to the LIRG/ULIRG regime and incorporates the [CII] deficit. We adopt a standard cosmology, which results in a luminosity distance of 1.6e4 Mpc for z~2.
For our galaxies, with a typical SFR~100 Mo/yr, we predict a [CII] luminosity of 1.6e9 Lsun, and a flux density of 146 mJy in a linewidth of 200 km/s if the object is unresolved. For the calculations in the OT we assume that 80% of the flux of the object is resolved in 2 beams (of 0.6") depending on the sizes of the galaxies, yielding an expected signal of 60 mJy over 200 km/s. The resulting S/N is 20-24 depending on the observation. For the Sargsyan et al. (2012) calibration we obtain a luminosity 4 times smaller (4e8 Lsun), which for the same assumptions will yield S/N~5-6. So we are garanteed to detect [CII].
In our two z=2.02 targets the spectral setup is designed to cover the maximum bandwidth to increase the chance of continuum detection, although our calculations suggest that we do not expect to detect the rest frame 160 um continuum. By tuning with [CII] in the LSB, the image sideband is placed in a transparent part of the atmosphere.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [CII] in zC405501
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Very high precision Ha redshift from SINFONI

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The S/N determination is covered in the previous science goal.
Our lowest metallicity galaxy is at z=2.15, which places the [CII] near the lower edge of the tunable range of the B9 LO. The redshift of the target is very well established, however, and the band covers +/-460 km/s around it, so we do not expect problems missing the emission. This target is in a less transparent part of the atmosphere and requires a longer integration. Unfortunately the presence of atmospheric absorption in the image band precludes attempting continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 370 um in zC405501
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 370 um continuum, chance for serendipitous detection of CO 7-6/[CI] in USB

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 3-2 in zC405501
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Get good S/N measurement of CO 3-2 in our lowest metallicity target Other windows are configured for continuum/serendipitous line detection

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on the PDR models mentioned in the [CII] science goal, we predict a CO 3-2 intensity of 0.75 mJy in a 200 km/s linewidth for this target, which is compatible with the measurement obtained by PHIBSS, and it is also compatible with measurements in similar low metallicity northern hemisphere PHIBSS targets (e.g., Genzel et al. 2012). We thus expect a S/N~5 with an on source integration of 50 minutes. Note that even though we expect to detect this source, even if we do not detect it the result would be important and provide a very strong limit for the "CO-dark" molecular gas and the CO-to-H2 conversion factor in this galaxy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Galaxy surveys in the past years show that the bulk of the massive star-forming galaxy (SFG) population forms a fairly tight sequence in stellar mass versus star formation rate, so-called "main sequence" of SFGs. Over the last few years, observations of the molecular gas content of these "normal" main-sequence SFGs at high redshift have been sampling increasingly smaller galaxy masses and subsolar metallicities, and already experience the problem of weak CO emission well known in local metal-poor galaxies. We propose to image the [CII] transition and dust continuum on three main-sequence galaxies at z~2 spanning a metallicity range Z~0.3-1 Zsun to: 1) obtain probes of the "CO-dark" H2 and investigate the gas mass and CO-to-H2 conversion factor in these objects, and 2) study the photoelectric heating efficiency in a regime not explored before. These galaxies are part of the PHIBSS/PHIBSS2 CO and SINFONI samples which provide key molecular gas, resolved Halpha, and metallicity information.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
